description: Situational – everyday partnership moments (plans, communication, boundaries, energy, quality, leadership). Answer how true each statement feels for you.

questions.question_text: If plans shift to a new place or activity I didn’t research, I’m comfortable pivoting and discovering as we go.
When invited to a themed community night or class that’s new to me, I’m likely to attend and try at least one thing.
questions.follow_up: What would help you feel comfortable trying something new?

questions.question_text: When the vibe turns from playful to focused, I can set or follow a brief intention so the moment feels meaningful (e.g., a breath, a phrase, a look).
Before big shared moments (date, trip, project), small rituals help me show up fully.
questions.follow_up: If you have one, what’s a small ritual that helps you arrive?

questions.question_text: If my partner seems hesitant mid-activity, I pause and check in without losing warmth or care.
For higher-stakes plans, I prefer clear safety plans and simple check-ins to guide us (before, during, after).
If conversation gets tangled, I can slow down, reflect back what I heard, and help restore shared language.
When I feel stirred up, I can regulate myself enough to name what I need (time-out, clarification, a breath) without escalating.
Under time pressure, I’m comfortable making a clear call and getting us moving, then refining on the fly.
In public or group settings, I can set boundaries with others confidently while keeping my partner centered.
Polish matters to me: I like aligning on standards (presentation, timing, setup) so the experience feels elevated.
I enjoy slowing down to improve technique together, even if it means fewer but higher-quality moments.
When the energy dips, playful challenges or tiny games help me re-ignite momentum for us.
I’m good at shifting a heavy or awkward mood toward lightness without ignoring feelings.
